The fraud of the "don't break Bitcoin" crowd,
And,
why @darosior philosophy is evil:

Imagine a bad code change to Bitcoin -- its so bad, it breaks everything -- it immediately crashes the node (like an assert(0) error)

What would happen in the real world? If that were released?

Um, nothing -- no one would run it. No one would be * even able * to run it. If they ran it, it would crash -- they would think that they had failed to install the new software in the first place. 

(It would have the same status, as the millions of versions of Bitcoin Core that are hypothetical but never released -- unusable)

This is why (contra Luke Dashjr) it is **backwards compatibility** and **the legitimacy of past versions** which protect Bitcoin. It is NOT ****"the absence of change"**** (whatever that means, in a world of ever-changing OS, dependences, requirements, ever-longer blockchain, growing userbase etc).

It is also why the hard fork is bad. When laypeople (who don't know the difference between hard fork and soft fork) say "don't change Bitcoin", they are talking about the hard fork.  

A "soft fork" is no different than any other code change -- except that the new feature is not safe to use until after miners upgrade. The op nop style softforks (explicitly inserted by Satoshi for the exact purpose of being used for upgrades) in particular carry zero risk, since miners could simply edit their template to ban any problematic op code from ever being spent to/from and it would be exactly as if the softfork had never existed.

So that is why it is false. But why is it also evil?

Well, because the whole thing is a shakedown of course. It is a USSR style power grab to make sure that any Bitcoin development that is actually useful, "goes through the proper channels" -- aka @darosior is the master and everyone else is his slaves

They imagine a world where Bitcoin Core is prestigious -- like an ivy league university or something, and they themselves are special board members -- they are the socialites who determine who gets accepted to the school. Is a soft fork safe? You have to ask them, every time. They are the permanent gatekeepers.

A permanently corrupt anti-meritocracy. (When in reality it is mafia style racketeering where they both create the problem and sell the solution.)

The more important reason why it is evil - is that Bitcoin has not yet prevailed. BTC does not currently have 8 billion happy users. In that sense, BTC is "broken" today, right now. Our work (in fixing it) is still cut out for us. Bitcoin will only succeed through **hard work** -- otherwise it will die. And @darosior 's philosophy is fundamentally opposed to that work. It is a philosophy emphasizing inaction over action -- it is a philosophy of complacency, not hard work.

Building an audience on X is a super power

Learn it and youre an unstoppable force

Here are 24 dead simple rules for building your following:

1. Send at least 1 post a day. Skipping a day lowers your algorithm score

2. Dont ask for anything from your audience. Exclusively give value

3. Formatting is everything. You can post the greatest idea in the world and if its unreadable nobody will look at it

4. Always proof read. Spelling and grammar mistakes come off as lazy. 

5. Proof read by reading your post out loud. You catch way more mistakes this way

6. Being on X all day can really damage your mental health. Limit yourself to only specific times

7. To be a good writer you need to be a good reader. Read books as much as you write posts. Better inputs = better outputs

8. When youre under 1000 followers keep your niche small. Be the loudest person in that niche

9. From 1000-5000 start expanding your niche. Interact with larger communities. Talk about broader subjects, but still stay in a niche

10. 5000-10000 you can start going for home runs. Youll be noticed now, so write more generalized tweets/threads about larger niches

11. Post with the same care and determination at 1 follower as you do at 1 million followers.

12. Form a pod. Choose 5 X accounts a similar size to you and interact with them every day. Youll grow together

13. Replying to other posts are critical. Reply to major accounts shortly after they post and youll get big exposure to a new audience

14. Always interact with people who reply to your posts. This is your core audience

15. Ignore the trolls. It's never worth it.

16. Speaking on an X Space every day will super charge your growth

17. Speaking of X Spaces: this is the most powerful tool in all of social media. Lose the fear and get on stage

18. Keep a notepad so you can write down ideas for posts throughout the day. The more you post, the more ideas youll get

19. If you live a busy life schedule your posts ahead of time. 

20. Be kind to others, itll naturally attract an audience to you much quicker

21. Monetizing too soon hurts your growth.

22. Quality over quantity. 1 quality post a day is better than 1000 throwaway posts

23. Enjoy the journey. It isnt about getting to a million followers. Its about the people you meet and the skills you learn along the way

Things every developer should know: JSON web token (JWT).

JWTs are one of the most widely used methods for API authentication, providing a secure, stateless and scalable way to verify clients.

Hereâ€™s a simple-to-understand breakdown of how it works, step by step:

1) Client authentication
The client (a user, app, or device) provides credentials (eg; username/password) to the authentication server.

2) Server verification
The authentication server checks the credentials against its database or identity provider to confirm their validity.

3) JWT issuance
If authentication is successful, the server:

â˜‘ Generates a JWT with claims (eg; user ID, roles, permissions).
â˜‘ Signs the JWT using a secret key (HS256) or a private key (RS256).

4) Token delivery
The server sends the signed JWT back to the client in the response.

5) Secure storage
The client stores the JWT securely to prevent unauthorized access. HTTP-only cookies are the most secure and widely used method.

6) API requests with JWT
For each request to a protected API, the client includes the JWT in the Authorization header: `Authorization: Bearer <JWT>`

7) Server validates the JWT
The API server verifies the JWT before granting access by checking:

â˜‘ Signature â€“ Confirms token integrity (not tampered with).
â˜‘ Expiration â€“ Ensures the token hasnâ€™t expired.
â˜‘ Audience (aud claim) â€“ Checks if the token is meant for this API.
â˜‘ Issuer (iss claim) â€“ Confirms the token was issued by a trusted authority.

If the JWT is valid, the server grants access to the requested resource. Otherwise, it rejects the request (401 Unauthorized).

8) Token expiration & refresh
Since JWTs expire for security reasons, the client needs a refresh token to get a new one:

â†³ Client sends refresh token to the server.
â†³ Server verifies & issues a new JWT if the refresh token is valid.
â†³ New JWT replaces the expired one, and the client continues making requests.

This workflow ensures secure, stateless, and efficient authentication for APIs while keeping performance and scalability in check.

Many are proposing "move 37" as evidence that AI has already reached Einstein-level intelligence, so I'd like to expand on this specific example.

Move 37, while impressive, is still essentially a straight-A student answer to the question posed by the rules of the game of Go.

Similarly, I'm quite convinced AI models will soon be able to come up with at least one formal mathematical proof that will be considered much more elegant than those developed by the best mathematicians to date.

But I don't think these truly qualify as the paradigm shifts we're discussing.

I believe an Einstein-level breakthrough in Go would involve something more fundamental, like inventing the rules of Go itselfâ€”exploring the vast landscape of possible game rules to create something genuinely more compelling than existing games.

Or in mathematics (a more apt analogy since games are human constructs unlike natural science), it might involve "discovering connections between previously unrelated mathematical fields to propose a new area of fruitful mathematical research" (which typically forms the basis of Fields Medal-winning work).

The bar for what constitutes an Einstein-level scientific paradigm shift remains really high in my opinion.

Missed Uniswap? Don't make the same mistake twice.

Ekubo is everything Uniswap should have been, but even better. Faster, cheaper, and more efficient.

And it's already live on Starknet and Ethereum.

Don't sleep on this ğŸ‘‡

1. What is @EkuboProtocol

Ekubo is a concentrated liquidity market maker on @Starknet.

It allows liquidity providers to concentrate their funds within specific price ranges, making trading more efficient with lower slippage and better capital efficiency.

Basically, Ekubo is a better version of Uniswap on Starknet and Ethereum.

2. Why is Ekubo Better And What Set it Apart ?

EkuboProtocol is designed to improve Uniswapâ€™s model in several key areas, particularly in gas efficiency, capital efficiency, and customization:

1âƒ£ Gas Efficiency: Lower Fees for Traders and LPs

â€¢ Singleton Contract Design

Unlike traditional AMMs where each pool has a separate smart contract, Ekubo manages all pools within a single contract.

This means when you interact with multiple pools in a single transaction (e.g., swapping across different token pairs), you donâ€™t need to call multiple contracts and therefore saving gas.

In a result, Ekubo is about 20% cheaper than Uniswap v3 and v4 for simple swaps, and even more cost-effective for multi-step swaps. Therefore, providers can earn better returns without needing as much capital as on other platforms.

2âƒ£ The â€œTillâ€ Pattern

Normally, every swap or liquidity update involves immediate token transfers, which increase gas costs.

Instead, Ekubo defers token transfers until the end of the transaction, batching them together for efficiency.

Result: Swaps and liquidity management on Ekubo are cheaper than on other AMM, making it more attractive for high-frequency traders and LPs.

Ekubo is always one step ahead as these innovations were only implemented only in Uniswap V4, making Ekubo a pioneer in introducing them.

3âƒ£ Concentrated liquidity

Even though Uniswap v4 improves gas efficiency, Ekubo still has a 100 X smaller tick size than Uniswap, meaning liquidity is much more concentrated. It means $1,000 in liquidity on Ekubo works as effectively as $100K on other AMMs.

LPs can focus their capital within a specific price range, increasing capital efficiency.

In traditional AMMs, liquidity is spread evenly across all possible prices, meaning a large portion of liquidity remains unused (except if the market price moves significantly)

Ekubo uses concentrated liquidity, allowing LPs to provide liquidity only within a specific price range of their choice. This means:

â€¢ LPs can allocate their capital more efficiently to the price ranges where most trading occurs.

â€¢ Traders get better price execution with lower slippage since more liquidity is available at the trading price.

â€¢  LPs earn higher returns because their capital is actively used rather than sitting and being unused.

While Uniswap V4 optimizes Uni tick size, the extent of those optimizations still not match Ekubo's in terms of how concentrated and efficient liquidity can be deployed within smaller ranges.

4âƒ£ Withdrawal Fee Incentives for LPs

Ekubo employs a fee switch mechanism that charges a fee on liquidity provider (LP) withdrawals equal to the fee tier of the pool. This creates a unique incentive for LPs to stay in the pool longer and allows the protocol to generate revenue.

In the future, as the protocol continues to grow, Ekubo will likely use its TWAMM (Time-Weighted Automated Market Maker) extension to automate buybacks of $EKUBO using protocol revenue, with the repurchased tokens being distributed to stakers with a model significantly more attractive compared to Uniswapâ€™s fee switch which focuses on redistributing trading fees for governance and token value enhancement.

5âƒ£ DCA Feature

Ekubo offers a feature called DCA (Dollar-Cost Averaging) via its first extension, the TWAMM (Time-Weighted Average Market Maker), which enables users to execute token sales over a specified time period. This feature is available in the user interface as "DCA orders" and "DCA-enabled" pools.

Great thread about Ekuboâ€™s DCA: https://t.co/tXsbr7Z1b0

6âƒ£ Permissionless Extensions for Developers

Ekubo allows developers to create custom pool types, such as on-chain oracles or limit orders. This enables more flexibility and customization for advanced DeFi strategies, while Uniswap v4 introduces some flexibility, but Ekubo's focus on permissionless extensions provides more room for custom DeFi products.

7âƒ£ Multihook

Multihook makes Ekubo more powerful by allowing multiple upgrades (extensions) to be added to a single liquidity pool instead of just one. This means developers can mix and match different features, control how they work together, and test new ideas without having to rebuild the pool from scratch. With support for up to 16 extensions, Multihook makes DeFi on Ekubo more flexible, customizable, and ready for advanced improvements like A51 Carbon (an initiative by Ekubo Protocol focused on advanced liquidity customization)

8âƒ£ Open Source Privacy Pools for Starknet

Ekubo has open-sourced an implementation of Privacy Pools for Starknet, inspired by the Privacy Pools concept introduced by Vitalik Buterin and others as an evolution of Tornado Cash.

Privacy Pools aim to balance financial privacy with regulatory compliance by allowing users to prove their funds originate from a legitimate set of deposits without revealing specific details.

By bringing this feature to Starknet, Ekubo invites the community to contribute to a more private (but compliant) financial ecosystem.

3. Ekubo Token and DAO

The EKUBO token has a total supply of 10 million tokens, distributed equally across three categories:

â€¢ Airdrop: 1/3 of the supply was distributed to users

â€¢ Team: 1/3 of the supply was distributed to the team

â€¢ DAO: 1/3 of the supply was distributed to the DAO and was sold to buy ETH, USDC, and STRK using Ekuboâ€™s DCA order feature

The Ekubo protocol is fully owned and operated by the DAO, with core contracts under its control rather than a multisig, reinforcing its commitment to decentralization.

Both the airdrop and team allocations were fully vested at TGE, while the DAOâ€™s portion was sold gradually after which EKUBO became fully diluted.

The DAO sale raised over $3 million combined with the DAOâ€™s revenue and the Starknet Catalyst grant where Ekubo was the top recipient with 6 Millions STRK received (=approx. $4.2M at that time)

Ekubo, Inc. is the creator of Ekubo Protocol, and the Ekubo DAO.

To sustain its role in the ecosystem, the company requested a $1.5M grant from the DAO to fund operations for the next two years, ensuring continued development without further funding.

Key Commitments:

â€¢ Develop & maintain core Ekubo contracts (including Cairo updates)

â€¢ Launch an on-chain limit order extension

â€¢ Design a revenue distribution framework for EKUBO stakers (Q1 2025)

â€¢ Host & maintain the Ekubo Interface (free for users)

â€¢ Provide governance tooling, developer support, and public API access

â€¢ Never sell the company's allocated 33.3% EKUBO tokens

The DAO will transfer $1.5M in ETH, STRK, and USDC to fund these efforts, covering 3-4 full-time hires.

$EKUBO Token:

For months EKUBO traded at 1$ / $EKUBO offering users the opportunity to buy at very low prices, and is now trading at >5X compared to its price at TGE, which is without any doubt a MASSIVE performance.

Ekubo does not rely only on their token. Their diversified approach improves financial stability and transparency.

Additionally, Ekubo's sale structure guaranteed that public buyers received the same terms as insiders, without later token unlocks, addressing the common concern that new tokens are often dominated by private market allocations.

4. Ekubo Adoption

While Volume and TVL stagnate for Ekubo, it is the same for Uni, mostly due to current market conditions

Furthermore, Ekubo has recently launched on Ethereum, which is expected to enhance its metrics and further its ambition to expand across other EVM chains. DEX aggregators on Ethereum, such as @matchaxyz, have already integrated Ekubo.

With projects like RosettaNET bringing EVM wallets to Starknet and the development of the Open Intent Framework, users will soon be able to seamlessly switch between chains, using their favorite wallets on Ekubo with ease.

5. Whatâ€™s next ?

â€¢ Focus on Ethereum for the next few months

â€¢ TWAMM extension on Ethereum

â€¢ Limit order extension

â€¢ Deploying on other EVM chains

6. Why Will Ekubo Succeed ?

As Uniswap, Ekubo
âœ” Is Capital-Efficient AMM 
âœ” Is Decentralized / DAO-led governance, ensuring community control.
âœ” Has Strong Token Incentives
âœ” Has User-Centric interface

But Better, Because: 

ğŸŒŸ Deployed on Starknet: Lower Fees, Higher Throughput

Unlike Uniswap on Ethereum, Ekubo benefits from ultra-low transaction costs and high scalability, making it more accessible for traders and LPs.

Temple Scams in India

I went to Kashi Vishwanath Temple today. I met someone at the entrance who was a Pandit. 

He proposed a quicker darshan for us and didnâ€™t ask for any priceâ€”he said we could give whatever we liked after the darshan and to think of it as a donation to a Brahmin. In my mind, I thought I would give him â‚¹500, and that would be fine.

But before we reached the darshan, he stopped us at a shop where he somehow tricked us into buying some pooja items that cost â‚¹1,100. Then we walked towards the temple. 

The route was still the same as the one taken by others; he was just moving us through the line faster. 

We waited in the queue for an hour, then did our darshan. After that, he took us to another temple in the same corridor, where he made us sit in front of another Pandit.

This Pandit chanted some mantras and then started asking for a â‚¹4,400 donation. I told him I had no money and that this was not something we had intended to do willingly, so why were they forcing us? 

I walked away from that place and told the first Pandit that they couldnâ€™t force us to donate, especially by playing this trick. He then tried to justify it with some ridiculous arguments about donations.

By the end of the whole darshan, when I gave him â‚¹500, the same guy who had said any donation was fine started asking for â‚¹2,100. He tried his best, and I ended up giving him â‚¹1,100. I ended up spending â‚¹2,200 on something I would call a scam that these guys are running in all major temples in India. 

They easily make â‚¹3,000 per day using the same trick, which amounts to around â‚¹90,000 every monthâ€”â‚¹1 million per year. You can easily find at least 100 such Pandits in the top 100 Indian temples. The scam force is around 10,000 people, extracting nearly â‚¹10 billion every year from tourists in the name of quick darshan.

And yet, tourists like me are also at fault. Not because we deserve to be scammed, but because we have fallen into a cycle where we demand shortcuts. 

The same mind that gets impatient while standing in a queue at a temple is the same mind that taps â€œSkip Adâ€ the moment it appears, the same mind that looks for express delivery even when regular delivery would do just fine. 

We have trained ourselves to crave speed, to avoid waiting, to get what we want instantly. And when someone exploits that craving, we fall for it without realizing we are being played. 

The irony is that we willingly pay for an illusion of privilegeâ€”the illusion that we are getting special access when, in reality, we are just another customer being processed through a well-oiled system of manipulation.

This is where the difference between serving demand and exploiting demand becomes clear. 

Take the lassi shop I visited later in Kashi. They sell around â‚¹3,000 worth of lassi every 10 minutes, easily making â‚¹60 million per year, just by selling lassi. But thereâ€™s no trickery there. 

No emotional manipulation. No false sense of exclusivity. They provide a product, and people pay for it because they genuinely want it. Thatâ€™s serving demand.

But what these Pandits are doing is something else. They arenâ€™t offering a service; they are feeding off peopleâ€™s impatience, off their vulnerability, off their desire to feel special. 

They have created an invisible tax on devotionâ€”a tax paid not in official currency, but in the currency of psychological manipulation. 

The tourist thinks they are getting something extra, but in reality, they are being led through the same corridors, standing in the same lines, just with a false sense of urgency and superiority.

And thatâ€™s the problemâ€”not just here, but everywhere. The market for instant gratification is far bigger than the market for genuine services. 

Because while people may hesitate to spend money on things they truly need, they rarely hesitate to spend money on things that make them feel like they are skipping the line.

"Itâ€™s a Great Project" Doesnâ€™t Mean Itâ€™s a Great Investment/Trade

Seen this cycle before - when markets shift into a less risk-on phase, people start justifying why theyâ€™re still holding certain tokens. â€œThe team is still building.â€ â€œIt has a great roadmap.â€ Howard Marks puts it well: just because something is great doesnâ€™t mean itâ€™s a great buy.

Projects - especially those higher up the "innovation" curve - run on narratives and flows. When risk appetite is high, people extrapolate the future, bidding up projects with strong teams and ambitious roadmaps, often well beyond fair value. But when conditions shift, those same projects can grind lower, regardless of fundamentals. There's an inverse correlation between duration premium (how much investors are willing to price in the long-term) and risk-off sentiment - when uncertainty rises, the market discounts the future harder.

Itâ€™s not that the project suddenly became worse (though this happens, especially when the token is already live - morale drops, teams lose motivation, some give up). Itâ€™s that people become less creative when things look bad. The same speculators, investors who once speculated on a big future now hesitate to price in anything beyond the present.

So the real question isnâ€™t just â€œIs this a good project?â€ but rather:
1) Is the market currently in a mode where itâ€™s willing to price in the future? If so, how much of that future is already accounted for in the current valuation?
2) Are there actual buyers, or just people waiting for conditions to improve?

It got something very basic wrong about me. I asked it where I live.

It was just one example that came up in an interesting conversation with @JoshuaJBouw and @bendiken about trustworthiness in AI and crypto (Joshua created the first proof of stake system). They visited my home, are visiting from Dubai.

Arto sees the world of AI needing to move to a new kind of AI that validates data and understands how it changes over time (and he's building such a system). Like my address. Shows that Grok isn't strongly integrated here on X yet, too. I can't wait until it is, would love to have it watch my lists. 

Yet another reminder that we don't yet have AGI.

ğŸ‡ºğŸ‡¸ SOUTH CAROLINA EXECUTES BRAD SIGMON BY FIRING SQUADâ€”FIRST IN 15 YEARS

Brad Sigmon, 67, was executed by firing squad in South Carolina, marking the first U.S. execution by this method in 15 years. 

Sigmon was convicted of murdering his ex-girlfriendâ€™s parents with a baseball bat in 2001.

He chose the firing squad over other methods due to concerns about suffering from lethal injection and electrocution. 

The execution took place at the South Carolina Department of Corrections in Columbia after the U.S. Supreme Court denied his final appeal.

Source: Reuters

The Arc litepaper v1 is now live. The design of arc, handshake, registry, forge and ryzome has taken a tremendous amount of collective effortâ€”from the engineers and designers working around the clock, to the advisors pushing us toward clarity, to the Arc Angels whose passion keeps the complex moving forward. Itâ€™s an honor to see everything come together.

There is a lot to unpack in the litepaper, but here is a summary of what's covered and why we're excited about the next phase of the arc ecosystem.

AI has been evolving fastâ€”from clever chatbots to autonomous agents capable of real-world impact. Yet weâ€™re still missing a fluid way for AI to integrate with our daily lives. We see a future where AI doesnâ€™t just advise us on, say, finding a cheaper flight, but handles the entire booking process end to end. For that to happen, agents must connect seamlessly to thousands of services and handle payments in a way that makes sense to both crypto natives and everyday users.

Thatâ€™s why weâ€™re introducing Ryzome, our universal â€œapp storeâ€ for agentic AI. Ryzome leverages Anthropicâ€™s Model Context Protocolâ€”think â€œHTTP for AIâ€â€”so agents can access just about any Web2 or Web3 service. Meanwhile, Arc token powers the economics under the hood, rewarding service providers with 85% of transaction fees, sending 10% to grow the ecosystem, and reserving 5% to keep the lights on.

But thereâ€™s more. For end users who would rather pay in USD or with a credit card, thatâ€™s fine. The system automatically converts to Arc, then pays the service providers on the backend. You get simplicity; service providers get trust and transparency.

We believe this will open up real possibilities for both developers and end users. The Arc Handshake program gives devs a fast track to launch AI services on Ryzome. Theyâ€™ll reach a global audience via ever expanding distribution channels and plug into a library of composable AI tools, all while enjoying a fair revenue split. For youâ€”the person who wants a personal finance manager, an all-in-one travel planner, or an automated research assistantâ€”it means a smarter, more unified experience.

The result, we hope, is a transformative ecosystem:
â€” Agents that actually do things, not just suggest them.
â€” A stronger Arc economy that aligns everyoneâ€™s incentives.
â€” A community-driven push toward a truly agentic future.

Take a moment to read the litepaper. Weâ€™re excited for you to see how Ryzome, Arc, and the broader ecosystem fit together. This is just the beginning of making AI not only smart, but capableâ€”truly capableâ€”of changing how we live and work.

Thank you for being part of this journey.

Going back and forth on whether MCP actually brings anything new

On the one hand, the idea that AI agents can and should communicate with each other in natural language is interesting

On the other hand, APIs do seem to cover most current use cases

I think I side with MCP being an advance, though, because of the ability to communicate nuanced intentions more easily and flexibly through natural language

It means the designer of the API doesn't have to try to guess at all the possible use cases, and can actually learn from the types of requests coming in as to what agents would like to do

I appreciate the passion and feelings that everyone has regarding whether I attend or am invited to specific US government events. Brigading government officials over X doesn't solve anything nor does it change hearts and minds. There will be many opportunities and ways to participate domestically and globally in the regulatory conversation. 

The most effective thing we can do as an ecosystem is focus on our ecosystem, its growth, and competitiveness. As events occur that give us the ability to engage, we will assess them on a case by case basis, but the direction is always clear: let's grow Cardano while preserving its core philosophy of decentralization. 

This movement has always been a human one that belongs to everyone. We haven't forgotten that over the last ten years, which is why I'm returning to our foundations in Japan. I'll continue to travel throughout the world to meet with you all, listen, learn, and build. It's a lifelong journey and one that's forever worth the time. 

Thank you all for being part of Cardano and contributing to our continued success.

there's a story behind the whole RPC thing. 

coming from Infura, I knew that RPC is one of the biggest attack factor of chain, aka the chain could run perfectly in real-time, but if the RPC breaks, the chain is effectively down. 

So early days, I urged my cofounders to identify a third party provider to work with us. 

ğŸ”¥guess what, they refusedğŸ”¥

on the ground that our chain has so much optimization, and none of the RPC providers match our performance.
 
the pros of this decision is that our RPC will be as fast as our chain

the cons of this decision is that it breaks since we lack devops experiences

big lesson learned here.

also, we really welcome more folks to stress test our chain. the beauty of crypto is to build in public, and we are following that ethos.

.@andrewrsorkin seems unsure how the US government could buy Bitcoin in a budget neutral way. There are a number of ways that more Bitcoin could be acquired:

- Asset Forfeiture:
The U.S. government already seizes Bitcoin through criminal and civil asset forfeiture. Expanding and streamlining these processes could increase the amount of Bitcoin acquired.

This is budget-neutral as the assets are obtained through legal proceedings, not direct purchases.

- Revaluation of Existing Assets:

There have been discussions about revaluing existing government assets, such as gold reserves, to current market prices. The increased valuation could create a "surplus" that could then be used to acquire Bitcoin.

- Strategic Sale of Non-Essential Assets:
The government could identify and sell non-essential assets, such as certain stockpiled commodities (our "strategic cheese reserve" ğŸ˜…) or underutilized properties (Yellowstone national park - I kid, I kid!), and use the proceeds to purchase Bitcoin.

@BitcoinPierre  has quipped that if you own a chair, you don't own enough Bitcoin (you should be standing more and sitting less). Obviously this is being a little flippant, but the idea has truth to it: if something is non-productive or has little growth potential, why not sell it and acquire the best performing asset of the last decade?

Building great tech doesnâ€™t guarantee a successful token. Founders, especially the ones who are here for the long game, are stuck in an impossible balancing act, pushing real innovation while constantly managing the communityâ€™s expectations around token price. Ignore the token, and youâ€™re accused of neglecting your holders. Focus too much on it, and suddenly, youâ€™re another pump and dump project with no real vision.

This dynamic forces founders into a cycle where survival depends not just on building something valuable, but also on keeping up with market narratives, speculation, and short-term hype. And letâ€™s be real, many projects donâ€™t even try to fight this. They lean into the casino model because itâ€™s easier. Play the right meta, spin up a narrative, pump the token, exit.

But blockchain as a tech has so much more to offer. Yet the space is still largely driven by speculative trading. The sad reality? Weâ€™re not just competing on tech; weâ€™re competing on attention. And in a market that moves this fast, attention always shifts to the next shiny thing.

So the question is 
WHEN DO WE BREAK THIS ? When do we stop optimizing for hype and start optimizing for real adoption? Because at some point, if we donâ€™t, we risk proving the skeptics right: that we built an industry more focused on narratives than real-world impact

If being popular was my goal, Iâ€™d jump on the cheerleading bandwagon for the announced strategic reserve as a game-changer like everyone else. Of course I am thrilled at the idea of a strategic reserve in the US where bitcoin is finally being recognized. But as someone who at times must be contrarian in seeking alpha, here are my thoughts for the many who follow me because I speak my mind for which I hope youâ€™ll appreciate that my views are still at large as aligned with anyone else who wants to see broad bitcoin adoption at the sovereign levelâ€“

People are comparing the EO strategic reserve as a breakthrough moment like when the Bitcoin spot ETFs launched, where the ST price action might go down near term but eventual institutional flows would come in and this would be a game changer. I disagree with this comparison. I think this is more similar to the ProShares futures-based Bitcoin ETF launch moment in 2021. Because while it is true that BITO raised a lot of money at the peak of market exuberance, it also found a material ceiling for â€œreal flowsâ€ as the product itself was fundamentally flawed. It also did not start the expected global arms race of spot ETFs to launch elsewhere.  Eventually, we would learn that we really needed the real thing, the spot ETF 3 years later to truly unleash the moment. We needed the US to first launch the real thing, not the fake thing, for the rest of the world to follow. Yet make no mistake that BITO was helpful in bridging the gap.

In my opinion, EO Strategic Reserve represents a similarly imperfect outcome. An EO is a singular political directive that can stick or disappear as easily as Bidenâ€™s EO on gender-affirming care for minors or the EO that sought to restrain the AI industry. Without the collective power of legislation that reflects the will of the peopleâ€™s coalition building, it is not likely the game-changing thing that kicks off a bunch of second order things people expect. People are generally already suspicious of the overreach of executive authority and one must account for there being a net negative that comes with these types of theatrics as well, especially for non-believers. So the question is: did we get enough net benefits against the costs?

At the core, we all know Trump is a transparently transactional person. He recognized that bitcoin, whether he believes in it or not, symbolized the ethos of his political capital and capitalized its base to the max to win the office. And all of this visually came down to this moment last night when you watch the video of his signing the EO. Before signing, he asks two questions: 1) "This is something YOU believe in, right?" 2) "And I made the promise, right?" What is happening here is a total relinquishment by transaction consummation. Trump is now officially â€œoff the hookâ€ for what the Bitcoin community did for him. If you want something else later, heâ€™ll want something else from now on.

And so in my humble opinion, we asked for too little. Having only bitcoin and not the rest of the altcoins in the strategic reserve by framing that as if it should have even been a considered question is not a win. â€œExploringâ€ or â€œstudyingâ€ concepts is not a win. â€œNot sellingâ€ is not a win. None of these things at the core require an EO at all to do anything. They are merely symbolic things that may kick off some events (or it may not). Comparing the current environment to Operation Chokepoint 2.0 and claiming we should now be â€œgratefulâ€ makes it sound like â€œbeing neutralâ€ is itself a win. Itâ€™s not. Chokepoint 2.0, SAB 121 were evil things. That canâ€™t be the benchmark for our industry to feel like we are owed to feel grateful for anything else. For the Bitcoin Roundtable fundraiser to have been one of the largest contributors to his election campaign, one must ask if this the â€œstrategic reserve dealâ€ that people had in mind at the time versus now. The fact that the Polymarket bet â€œWill Trump create bitcoin reserve in the first 100 days?â€ is still sitting at <50% â€œyesâ€ today reflects the ambiguity of this expectation. In other words, promises were made, but the market is not sure if promises were kept, though the one thing for sure is that now Trump is off the hook.

Maybe this is the best we can do for now. It doesnâ€™t mean the crypto council, policymakers, lobbyists and the executive team are not doing all the best they can. Iâ€™m sure they did and are. At the same time, it is rational to consider disappointment if this represents the culminating moment of peak performance since November and consider this is a short-term bearish set up. We are so used to being treated so badly that we are conditioned to think every small thing is the biggest win ever. My one ask for the industry is that we strive to set our bars higher, where we demand really meaningful things so we can celebrate really meaningful things, especially as we head into the heat of the two most important things that will come out of Congress: market structure and stablecoin legislations. We deserve it, and we helped elect a lot of people for it. Hold them all accountable for real progress. Then after the hard work is done, let's celebrate those wins when we cross the finish line.

Comparing the current environment to Operation Chokepoint 2.0 and claiming we should now be â€œgratefulâ€ makes it sound like â€œbeing neutralâ€ is itself a win. Itâ€™s not. Chokepoint 2.0, SAB 121 were evil things. That canâ€™t be the benchmark for our industry to feel like we are owed to feel grateful for anything else. For the Bitcoin Roundtable fundraiser to have been one of the largest contributors to his election campaign, one must ask if this the â€œstrategic reserve dealâ€ that people had in mind at the time versus now. The fact that the Polymarket bet â€œWill Trump create bitcoin reserve in the first 100 days?â€ is still sitting at <50% â€œyesâ€ today reflects the ambiguity of this expectation. In other words, promises were made, but the market is not sure if promises were kept, though the one thing for sure is that now Trump is off the hook.

Maybe this is the best we can do for now. It doesnâ€™t mean the crypto council, policymakers, lobbyists and the executive team are not doing all the best they can. Iâ€™m sure they did and are. At the same time, it is rational to consider disappointment if this represents the culminating moment of peak performance since November and consider this is a short-term bearish set up. We are so used to being treated so badly that we are conditioned to think every small thing is the biggest win ever. My one ask for the industry is that we strive to set our bars higher, where we demand really meaningful things so we can celebrate really meaningful things, especially as we head into the heat of the two most important things that will come out of Congress: market structure and stablecoin legislations. We deserve it, and we helped elect a lot of people for it. Hold them all accountable for real progress. Then after the hard work is done, let's celebrate those wins when we cross the finish line.

If most Bitcoin supply is held by early whales, governments, ETFs, and institutions like Strategy, how much is actually circulating?

As mainstream interest grows, newcomers are scrambling for what seems to be a tiny fraction of the supply. Bitcoinâ€™s role as a store of value is clear, but we should also acknowledge that the â€œmountainsâ€ have already been strip-mined.

As global adoption accelerates, weâ€™re asking people to invest in something they must buy from others, often through intermediaries like ETFs, adding layers of separation from the real asset. Similar to the gold market, very few people buying today actually own their Bitcoin directly.

This isnâ€™t meant to be a bearish takeâ€”just a question of how new entrants navigate this reality. And if our goal is a decentralized, unstoppable digital currency/SOV free from government control, why do so many Bitcoiners I see celebrate its increasing centralization and abstraction?

When an Entrepreneur Meets Nation Builders

My fascination with history and science has always gone beyond textbooks. Iâ€™ve dived deep into couple of IAS curriculum coursesâ€”not for a career in civil service, but simply because I love learning how the world works.

And that same curiosity recently took me somewhere extraordinary: the Lal Bahadur Shastri National Academy of Administration (LBSNAA) in Mussoorie.

I was invited to speak with 140 civil service officers from the 2004 batch, part of the governmentâ€™s mid-career training program. But this wasnâ€™t just another talk.

Letâ€™s be honestâ€”when you think of bureaucrats, you probably picture rigid rules, red tape, and an army of file-pushers. But these officers? They shattered every stereotype.

Sharp. Fearless. Unapologetically curious.

What was supposed to be a presentation on OYOâ€™s journey quickly turned into a rapid-fire exchange of ideas. They didnâ€™t want a well-rehearsed speech. They wanted the raw, unfiltered truth.

"How do you tackle regulatory hurdles in an ever-changing landscape?"
"Whatâ€™s the one thing that keeps you up at night when scaling a company?"
"Where do business and governance truly intersectâ€”and where do they clash?"

Their questions werenâ€™t just insightful; they cut straight to the core of real-world challenges.

And thatâ€™s when I had my biggest realizationâ€”thereâ€™s an untapped synergy between private sector agility and public sector vision. These officers arenâ€™t just running systems; theyâ€™re rethinking them. Theyâ€™re strategists, problem-solvers, and in many ways, entrepreneurs in their own right.

I walked into LBSNAA expecting to share knowledge. I walked out with a renewed perspective.

Because sometimes, the most game-changing conversations happen in the most unexpected places.

AI isn't the future of media. It's the foundation beneath all future media. This distinction matters profoundly. When we call something "the future," we position it as a destination, something that will eventually arrive and replace what came before. AI systems aren't simply the next stage in media's evolution. I think it's becoming the substrate that transforms how all media is created, distributed, and experienced.

Writers use AI to refine their drafts and explore ideas. Musicians collaborate with generative systems to discover new harmonies. Filmmakers use AI for everything from script development to visual effects. It is and will be beneath all future media.

Many crypto projects consider Korea as their exit liquidity, but now we need to think about what we can build on top of this market.

According to the Financial Supervisory Service of Korea, the four major Korean exchanges (Upbit, Bithumb, Coinone, Korbit) hold approximately 9 trillion won (approximately $6.2 billion) in KRW deposits. This trend will continue to expand as the crypto market grows.

Additionally, as we all know, the most compelling use case for stablecoins is as a quote currency on exchanges. The reason Korean won stablecoins currently lack influence is that, unlike exchanges in other countries, Korean exchanges allow users to purchase crypto assets directly with fiat currency rather than using stablecoins.

If the four major Korean exchanges were to trade crypto assets using stablecoins pegged to the Korean won, it would mean we could issue stablecoins worth approximately $6.2 billion.

This is possible because Koreans are passionate about crypto trading. While foreign projects have so far used this volume to increase their token prices, now we should also issue stablecoins and develop stablecoin-related businesses based on rapid market share growth.

If Korean stablecoins were issued, it would indicate that tremendous liquidity could flow into on-chain systems. Similar to Tether and Circle, if private entities in Korea create won-based stablecoins under government regulation, various Layer 1 blockchains would actively cooperate to enable the issuance of won stablecoins on their chains to attract this liquidity, and diverse DeFi pools could be established.

Once won stablecoins begin circulating across various Layer 1 networks, we can implement different businesses on top of them. Now we need to consider what advantages Korea has in the crypto industry and not just remain a "trading market." We need to contemplate businesses and strategies that are possible specifically because of Korea's proactive investment mindset.

In this regard, this stablecoin seminar was a very meaningful event, and as a research company, we were happy to share what we have learned with regulatory authorities and industry colleagues.

the @maplestoryu ceo just dropped his thesis on crypto gaming

why web3 gaming is the next big step:

not everyone plays games due to time, money, and mental energy barriers

over time the gaming industry evolved to break down these barriers

1. free-to-play model removed financial barriers in early 2000s
2. mobile gaming eliminated time constraints in 2010s -> casual gaming integrated into daily life for non-gamers
3. streaming created spectator gaming experiences -> games became less self-contained, more social and emergent

now we get to web3

web3 is the next frontier in gaming evolution because it enables players to generate real economic value (makes it possible to turn a passion into a career) but is more than just play-to-earn mechanics

players win by becoming active participants, not just consumers

----
all in all nothing we haven't heard before (and a tad generic) but it does hit harder when it comes from a team and a company that arguably made a top 5 mmo of all tim

not to mention they set aside $100m to invest into this game

maplestory u becoming a success would be massive for the space because a name like that sends signals to the wider industry and would trigger an influx of new blood into the industry (something it really needs right now)

if you're in crypto gaming you want to see maplestory win

I've been pondering this idea for about 4 years now.

The concept behind Heavy Bitcoin is that bitcoin nodes have become more and more advanced up to the point of becoming autonomous roaming tanks.

The noderunner and the node tank go on adventures together. Stuff happens, explosions, snark, you get the point.

I started that novel but it hadn't yet gelled for me so I worked on other stories.

I recently watched Frieren and loved how the low time-preference was shown there, how she has to deal with long-term thinking in a world that moves too fast for her. That inspired me to come up with a similar theme in a post-apocalyptic future, and I thought, "This fits into the Heavy Bitcoin world."

So I'm now working on that sequel story. The hero is a genetically engineered human that lives for a long time and has a small node tank along with him. He lives in a world where technology has broken down and knowledge has been lost, so he's roaming the land and fixing things. Others think it's magic.

This happens to me often, I come up with a campaign setting book, I set it aside and then come up with a more interesting story to tell based on that setting. If this goes well I might work on the original campaign setting that explains all the backstory.

I'll post some chapters when I'm further in.

The First Crypto Summit: What to Expect & How to Capitalize (March 7, 2025) â€“ 

Today is a day that will go down in crypto history.

The worldâ€™s first-ever Crypto Summit is happening at the White House, bringing together the biggest names in the industryâ€”Vitalik Buterin, CZ, Brian Armstrong, Anatoly Yakovenko
and more.

For the first time, the U.S. government is sitting down with cryptoâ€™s top innovators and leaders to decide the future of the industry.

Regulations, tax policies, institutional adoptionâ€”itâ€™s all on the table.

Why This Summit Matters?
âœ Crypto in the White House: 
The U.S. President will directly engage with the crypto industry.

This meetup is unprecedented 

âœ Regulations Are Coming: 
Whether good or bad, crypto policy clarity is near.

âœ Market Impact Might Be Huge: The decisions made here could define the next decade of crypto.

Soâ€¦ whatâ€™s on the agenda? And more importantly, how do you capitalize?

Here's the possible Bullish & Bearish Scenarios: What Could Happen?

Bullish ScenarioğŸ‘‡
1. U.S. Expands the Crypto Strategic Reserve:
Rumors suggest Trump could add more assets to the governmentâ€™s crypto reserves.

3. Clear Regulatory Framework

Bearish Scenario

3. Exclusion of Certain Cryptos from the Strategic Reserve:

How to Capitalize on This EventğŸ‘‡
1. Stay calm â†’ Sometimes, not making a move is also a move.
The market is at a crossroads, bullish or bearish, everything seems in between.
This summit could set the tone for the next phase, but until clarity comes, donâ€™t overcommit.

2. Watch Which Coins Are Mentioned â†’ If new assets are added to the Crypto Strategic Reserve, they might pump.

3. Look for Regulation-Friendly Projects â†’ If stablecoins, RWAs, or institutional DeFi get the green light, these sectors might boom.

4. Monitor Institutional Interest â†’ If major firms publicly support the summitâ€™s outcomes, expect long-term bullish momentum.

Yes, history is being made today, but weâ€™re at a crossroads.

The first-ever White House Crypto Summit could mark the beginning of a true bull market or not.

No one knows for sure what happens next.

But one thingâ€™s clear: all eyes are on crypto today.

Growing businesses require new systems that can accommodate their expansion: @animecoin 

Anime 1.0: The Era of the Production Committee System

I believe that Anime 1.0 represents the golden age that took place under the Production Committee System. The Japanese animation industry experienced its first golden age with the emergence of production committees, where multiple sponsors jointly invested in animations and distributed profits according to investment ratios. Thanks to production committees, animation studios not only reduced the burden of initial production costs but also dispersed the risk of losses, allowing talented animation producers to more actively pursue creating "good works."

This helped the animation industry grow, and Japan literally entered the first renaissance of the animation industry.

But now the animation industry has changed.

Animation is no longer a product consumed by a small number of "otaku" in Japan, but has become a hobby enjoyed by people of all ages and nationalities. Naturally, the globalization of such content has been greatly contributed to by the diversification and globalization of animation distribution networks through OTT and internet streaming services.

The problem is, despite the market growth, the approach remains similar. Animation has become global entertainment, yet they still create and distribute animations using the production committee method.

When an industry changes, the system must change too.

What's needed is a means to distribute and deliver IP more freely, without borders, to more people efficiently. And a tool that can invest in works more dynamically and provide "self-sustainability" to enable diverse works to emerge.

That tool is blockchain.

Blockchain has successfully presented token funding as a new method of financing. Although memes currently dominate, animation might become intellectual property worthy of investment as a "sustainable meme." The prosperity of the memecoin market might be proof that on-chain animation can succeed.

The "self-sustainability" provided by blockchain also notably allows fans to engage in secondary transactions and derivative creations more freely.

It's time to move beyond the production committee system.

In this context, I look forward to the mainnet launch of Anime. They are a team that has already successfully launched @Azuki, a massive IP in the Web3 market, and successfully distributed it to traditional markets. I myself am captivated by their IP and own @Azuki .

I think Anime is strategically excellent. They built their chain not as an independent Layer 1 but as a Layer 3, targeting the animation industry which they are most confident in and excel at. The size of that market also promises significant upside potential if successful.

I believe the current situation of the animation market, the maturity of blockchain technology, and the capabilities of Anime Coin's key contributors all point to success. That's why watching @animecoin's growth this year should be very interesting.

the ticker is $Anime

For more detailed information about Anime Industry's history and why we need blockchain for anime, please check out @13300RPM's article.

My favorite life lesson is this -

generally, people can be grouped into two distinct categories.
- the journey enjoyers 
- the destination seekers 

their titles are exactly what you think they would be - every being must answer the question - for the journey, or the destination?

it is in your utmost interest to group everyone you meet into one of these categories as effectively and efficiently as possible, in order to stray away an unfortunate life.

neither side is inherently bad or good, itâ€™s entirely dependent on which side you categorize yourself in

> the journey enjoyer

these tend to be the most morally in-line people youâ€™ll meet, and arguably the best friend/companion you can choose 

journey enjoyers do simply just that, they enjoy the journey.

they find they happiness and enjoyment in each day, the events and actions they consist of. 

there is no â€œgoalâ€ - they simply wake and sleep each day without focusing on too large of a picture 

most importantly, these are the people that befriend you simply because they enjoy the friendship. they donâ€™t consider anything to be transactional.

they exist, and they are happy. more often than not, these will be the friends you can hold onto for a lifetime.

> the destination seeker

destination seekers have a defined goal/goals in mind, and to seek to gain value throughout their journey

each day should be better than the previous, gaining value in some sense, whether itâ€™s knowledge, experience, or financial gain 

the value is achieved through personal work and mass networking 

each and every friendship should have value to be extracted, they will never be 100% organic 

is it a parasitic approach? no - but it can be if you donâ€™t understand who ur dealing with.

treat a destination seeker with a destination seeker approach, and youâ€™ll live a much more fruitful and valuable life than any journey enjoyer ever would.

but, allowing such people to extract value without making such things mutual, is extremely detrimental.

-

you can make your arguments for one side being better than the other, or one being morally aligned more than the other. but there is certainly no correct answer. beauty is in the eye of the beholder.

figure out which of the two categories you are, and take an approach accordingly. 

not knowing this can get you surrounded with the wrong people for yourself and get you into a hole you wonâ€™t be able to get out of 

my favorite lesson ever

There still seems to be a lot of confusion about what leverage is, what it means and how it should be used.

The question: "What leverage do you use" is irrelevant.

Leverage is used to limit your counter party risk. It helps you take larger positions while having minimal collateral/margin on the exchange you're trading at.

It should NOT be used to increase position size to sizes which you wouldn't otherwise be taking if you'd be trading spot only for example.

Your position size and stop loss determines the risk you take every trade. So whether you take a $100 position with $10 margin and 10x leverage or a $100 position with 1$ margin and 100x leverage is perfectly the same.

Just make sure you measure out your risk and stop loss in advance.

â€œWhat I mean: all based rollups are essentially a single sequencer that concatenates n chains together; but instead of doing it directly like a simple high-performance chain, it has to deal with political coordination and management of intricate security interdependencies of a dozen of teams. I can elaborate on the technical details if needed.â€

If this was correct I would agree with the rest. The thing is that itâ€™s not. 

1. based rollups are not a single sequencer. you can have as many sequencers as you want. it just means youâ€™re doing the sequencing in the same validator set of the l1
2. sequencing has nothing to do with a high performance chain. itâ€™s just how you sequence the l1 with l2 or l2 witu l2s transaction. you do these things via the same box when you have transactions that go from one place to another
3. token price of Ethereum is one of the reason why some people are doing this. iâ€™m not, i want composability between L2s. rollup clusters is fragmenting ethereum. we need a solution. users will win by having based rollups.
4. there is no contradiction between scaling the L1 and based rollups. based rollups donâ€™t need any change in the L1. no need to put them as contradictory. itâ€™s like saying that making the L1 faster implies that we need to stop ZK from moving forward. you will see many solutions working in production very soon with different tradeoffs.

based rollups enable cross rollup interoperability. you talk about this needing political change and coordination but you propose to enshrine a shared bridge in ethereum. itâ€™s easier to launch new solutions that solve UX problems for users rather than convincing optimism or zksync to use the same shared bridge. your proposal is even more political.

based rollups will get more adoptions and people convinced by the month. they will happen, some clusters will move into it. others wonâ€™t and thatâ€™s ok. we can have different solutions but I believe the ones supporting based sequencing will have concrete advantages for many usecases.

Ethrex by @class_lambda and reth by @paradigm proven with RISC-V zkVMs commoditized the stack of many teams. I still remember the debates from two years ago about what would be best. They are irrelevant now. The technical motto for the EVM chains wil disappear. Alt VMs actually can have an advantage if they can do things EVM ones canâ€™t.

With one click you will be able to launch zk rollups with transactions costing a penny. 

In a few months to a year with based sequencing you will have composability between different clusters. With @gattacahq and @class_lambda we built a first working version. @Spire_Labs has a different flavor with some advantages and other disadvantages. @taikoxyz has been by far the one moving fastest. Many other teams are pushing for this to become a reality too. We have different visions but weâ€™re all pushing for interoperability between the L2s.

ZK proving became a reality fast enough. Based sequencing will become a reality too and we will be pushing for it to happen.

Buying #Bitcoin might have been a bit burdensome.

In fact, even though this Bitcoin Strategic Reserve EO is quite positive news, I think the market is selling off because expectations for Trump were too high.

Considering @worldlibertyfi and @EricTrump's statements so far, it would have been reasonable to expect not just the government strategically reserving Bitcoin it already owns, but also steadily purchasing more Bitcoin, and even possibly extending purchases to major altcoins(namely, $ETH, and $SOL).

However, in a situation where public perception of Bitcoin isn't extremely positive yet, the act of purchasing Bitcoin with government funds could potentially conflict with the "don't waste money on unnecessary things" agenda(@DOGE Agenda) that the Trump administration is currently promoting.

Of course, whether investing in Bitcoin is a waste of money - from my perspective or industry insiders' view, it isn't - but from an outsider's perspective, it certainly could be seen that way. And since markets won't always perform well, during price declines or bear markets, there would certainly be critical public opinion about "purchasing Bitcoin."

I think they might have recognized these aspects as well.

Nevertheless, I believe it's positive enough just knowing that Bitcoin seized by the government in the future might not be sold on the market but rather continuously reserved by the government.

I think it's better not to have too high expectations about Trump calling himself the "Crypto President." Politicians typically have a special talent for being the "President for the common people" in front of common people, and the "President for businesses" in front of businesspeople.

While Trump is unlikely to view crypto negatively during his term, it also seems wise to abandon expectations that he'll make crypto his top priority. Crypto is just one of many political agenda for him.

The rise of AI, copilots, and automation is changing how businesses create and deliver value, with many shifting from selling tools to selling outcomes. As AI-driven software moves toward usage-based pricing, some businesses are moving away from traditional subscription models, where customers pay for seats or licenses, to pricing models that are based on actual usage or performance. This shift is pushing companies to potentially rethink their billing infrastructure, from real-time usage tracking to finance system integrations. This shift could create ripple effects across the entire billing stack and can impact CRM, CPQ, CLM, ERP, and more.

Continuing from last weekâ€™s post on the rise of the Voice Stack, thereâ€™s an area that todayâ€™s voice-based systems often struggle with: Voice Activity Detection (VAD) and the turn-taking paradigm of communication.

When communicating with a text-based chatbot, the turns are clear: You write something, then the bot does, then you do, and so on. The success of text-based chatbots with clear turn-taking has influenced the design of voice-based bots, most of which also use the turn-taking paradigm.

A key part of building such a system is a VAD component to detect when the user is talking. This allows our software to take the parts of the audio stream in which the user is saying something and pass that to the model for the userâ€™s turn. It also supports interruption in a limited way, whereby if a user insistently interrupts the AI system while it is talking, eventually the VAD system will realize the user is talking, shut off the AIâ€™s output, and let the user take a turn. This works reasonably well in quiet environments.

However, VAD systems today struggle with noisy environments, particularly when the background noise is from other human speech. For example, if you are in a noisy cafe speaking with a voice chatbot, VAD â€” which is usually trained to detect human speech â€” tends to be inaccurate at figuring out when you, or someone else, is talking. (In comparison, it works much better if you are in a noisy vehicle, since the background noise is more clearly not human speech.) It might think you are interrupting when it was merely someone in the background speaking, or fail to recognize that youâ€™ve stopped talking. This is why todayâ€™s speech applications often struggle in noisy environments.

Intriguingly, last year, Kyutai Labs published Moshi, a model that had many technical innovations. An important one was enabling persistent bi-direction audio streams from the user to Moshi and from Moshi to the user.

If you and I were speaking in person or on the phone, we would constantly be streaming audio to each other (through the air or the phone system), and weâ€™d use social cues to know when to listen and how to politely interrupt if one of us felt the need. Thus, the streams would not need to explicitly model turn-taking. Moshi works like this. Itâ€™s listening all the time, and itâ€™s up to the model to decide when to stay silent and when to talk. This means an explicit VAD step is no longer necessary. (Moshi also included other innovations, such as an â€œinner monologueâ€ that simultaneously generates text alongside the audio to improve the quality of responses as well as audio encoding.)

Just as the architecture of text-only transformers has gone through many evolutions (such as encoder-decoder models, decoder-only models, and reasoning models that generate a lot of â€œreasoning tokensâ€ before the final output), voice models are going through a lot of architecture explorations. Given the importance of foundation models with voice-in and voice-out capabilities, many large companies right now are investing in developing better voice models. Iâ€™m confident weâ€™ll see many more good voice models released this year.

It feels like the space of potential innovation for voice remains large. Hard technical problems, like the one of latency that I described last week and VAD errors, remain to be solved. As solutions get better, voice-to-voice will continue to be a promising category to build applications in.

"By far the most popular research note I ever wrote had the title, 'We're Wrong Here.' You spend a lot of time on an idea and you're really personally invested in the thesis, and you have to just let go. And that's hard."  -Jay Van Sciver @HedgeyeIndstrls 

ğŸ”Š

Everyone makes mistakesâ€”but in investing, the real question is whether you have the courage and process to own them and learn from them.

In this clip from "The Call @ Hedgeye," @KeithMcCullough and veteran Industrials analyst Jay Van Sciver have a candid discussion on why it's so difficult for investors and analysts to walk away from a call or a stock pick, no matter their experience level.

The emotional attachment to an idea can cloud judgment, leading investors to hold on too long. 

McCullough puts it bluntly:

"When you spend a lot of time in the weeds, you can get stuck. But at the end of the day, it's just a ticker. You never have to own or short anything."

He continues: "These are not your kids and sending them off to school. They're tickers. Just because you did a lot of work on it doesn't mean you stay with it. If the market gets you first and you lose money, then you're not good at this."
